docs.snippet: Though the hosts, James Franco and Anne Hathaway, joked about being the "hip" Oscars from the start of the show, and then acted on it, their performances drew decidedly mixed reviews....
docs.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES - So how did the Academy Awards do as a cultural mash-up? Not so hot. Though the hosts, James Franco and Anne Hathaway, joked about being the "hip" Oscars from the start of the show and then acted on it -- Mr. Franco unleashed a torrent of backstage Twitter posts, and Ms. Hathaway mentioned drinking games -- their performance drew decidedly mixed reviews, especially when compared with the riffing of the 94-year-old Kirk Douglas. The "Auto-Tune the News" segment was a bit of a head-scratcher. And the use of the fifth-grade choir from Staten Island's P.S. 22, a YouTube sensation known for its renditions of pop and indie songs, was denuded by singing "Somewhere Over the Rainbow" as the credits rolled. Don't get us wrong, it was still cute (and the shot of Melissa Leo singing along was sweet, especially after she dropped an obscenity in her remarks accepting her Supporting Actress Oscar). But it could have been much sharper. What did you think?
docs.abstract: Though the hosts, James Franco and Anne Hathaway, joked about being the "hip" Oscars from the start of the show, and then acted on it, their performances drew decidedly mixed reviews.

headline.main: A Mixed Bag of a Cultural Mash-Up

docs.snippet: Student Opinion | What do you do to help manage the stress in your life?...
docs.lead_paragraph: As many school districts are forced to tighten their budgets, school officials are faced with difficult choices regarding eliminating or cutting back on sports programs and gym classes. What suggestions do you have for students who want to stay active and relieve stress when joining a sports team or relying on gym class isn't an option?

docs.snippet: Getting the fifth-grade chorus of P.S. 22 in Staten Island was a sweet though inscrutable musical choice, but here's one theory: yes, younger demographics....
docs.lead_paragraph: Now that was a musical finale: the fifth-grade chorus from P.S. 22 in Staten Island singing "Over the Rainbow." The kids gave it their all in their color-coded T-shirts - green for sopranos, blue for altos - as they made hand gestures and moved into some kind of formation near the end. Was that a butterfly?
docs.abstract: Getting the fifth-grade chorus of P.S. 22 in Staten Island was a sweet though inscrutable musical choice, but here's one theory: yes, younger demographics.

headline.main: A Musical Finale, Demographically in Tune

docs.snippet: Three of the contenders for the best picture Oscar were gone from theaters when the nominees were announced on Jan. 26: ''Toy Story 3'' (closed Dec. 2), ''Inception'' (Jan. 6) and ''The Kids Are All Right'' (Oct. 21). Five of the remaining films h...
docs.lead_paragraph: Three of the contenders for the best picture Oscar were gone from theaters when the nominees were announced on Jan. 26: ''Toy Story 3'' (closed Dec. 2), ''Inception'' (Jan. 6) and ''The Kids Are All Right'' (Oct. 21). Five of the remaining films have taken in substantially more since then, especially ''127 Hours'' and ''The King's Speech.'' The best picture for 2009, ''The Hurt Locker,'' above, with Jeremy Renner, was also out of theaters when nominees were announced. It was re-released the Friday before the awards show, and increased its ticket sales by 26 percent to $17 million. SHELLY FREIERMAN
docs.abstract: Shelly Freierman Popular Demand column on contenders for best picture Oscar; photo (M)
